text: I think sometimes as Christians we read the Bible and read about God doing these miraculous works, and we think, wow, wouldn’t it have been cool to live then, maybe in the Old Testament where God was manifesting Himself in powerful, miraculous ways, or in the Book of Acts with lots of miracles going on. But God chose you to live now. Believe me, the people then would have coveted to live this close to Christ’s return, so never covet somebody else’s time in history because you’ve been blessed.
Pastor Chuck Smith, who many of us respect, said, 'The most important thing a born-again Christian can do is pray.'
Spurgeon said, 'I would rather teach one man to pray than ten men to preach.'
John Bunyan, the author of Pilgrim's Progress, said, 'You can do more than pray after you have prayed, but until we pray, we can't do more than pray.'

We need to hear them being shouted from Afghanistan right now. There are Americans who need to get out, people who’ve helped us over the last 20 years who we’ve made commitments to. You need to hear a shout from the other side of the planet saying, 'Pray for us.'
There are people who are hurting in Haiti. You need to hear this cry coming up for prayer.
There are Christians who are being persecuted around the world. You need to hear this cry for prayer coming up.
There are people in Cuba who are believers, being shut down by their government. You need to hear this cry for prayer.
You also need to hear it from the souls of your children who are in bondage to sin. Maybe it’s not coming out of their lips, but their hearts are crying, 'Pray for us.'

I loved how John Courson would talk to non-Christians like they were already Christians. He’d be in the gym locker room, hear someone use the name of the Lord in vain, and say, 'Oh, you know Him too? Isn’t He wonderful?'

John Courson was heading to a retreat for his church youth group and stopped at a gas station. He said to the young attendant, a total stranger, 'Hey, I’m going up to a retreat right now, and I could really use some prayer. Would you just pray for me right now?'

After John Courson asked that gas station kid to pray for him, guess who was in church the next Sunday when John was preaching? Guess who gave his life to Christ within about two weeks? God works through prayer in ways we have yet to discover.

Last week I preached about authority, including government authority, from Hebrews, because church leaders were telling people to submit and obey. Somehow, repeated numbers of people got convinced I was teaching that Christians need to get the vaccination. I’ve checked my fillings, and I don’t know where anybody could’ve gotten that, to be honest with you, but the fact that so many did tells me it’s my fault, my failure.
Remember when Jesus went up on the Mount of Transfiguration? He comes down, and there’s a man who’s brought his demon-possessed son to the disciples.

I was thinking, and I often think of the parable of the Prodigal Son, which, by the way, Jesus never called it that. That's what we call it. There's great truths in there, and it really is the story of the self-righteous older brother as well.

You remember the story of the prodigal son, how he plans to say to his father, 'Father, I've sinned against heaven and in your sight. I'm not worthy to be called your son; hire me as one of your hired servants.' But the father interrupts him, falls on him with love, and says, 'You're not going to work for me; you're my boy. You were dead, but you're alive; you were lost, but now you're found.'
When I go to a restaurant and they wait on me, they're serving me. When I wait on the Lord, I'm serving Him. To wait on the Lord means to hope in God, to trust God's promises actively.

In the Old Testament, King Asa of Judah faced a million-man Ethiopian army early in his reign. Overwhelmed, he cried out to the Lord, 'God, we can't stand against them, you're gonna have to help!' And God moved, gave him victory, and established him in his kingdom.

Years later, King Asa is attacked by King Baasha of Israel during a civil war between the two kingdoms. Instead of talking to the Lord, Asa makes an alliance with a foreign king, Ben-Haddad, saying, 'Hey, we've got a deal, I'm being attacked, you attack him and he'll stop preparing to attack me.'

One time when Paul is standing before the high priest and some of the leaders who are questioning him, he says, 'I have kept a good conscience from my youth.' And the high priest ordered him to be slapped in the face, like that's a lie. None of us can say that, but Paul was committed to having a clean and clear conscience.
It's kind of like I'm putting this problem in God's in-basket. He did say, 'Cast your cares upon me,' so I'm saying, 'Houston, Heaven, you've got a problem.' I'm turning this over to the Lord.

A man had a demon-possessed son who would often throw himself into the fire or water to drown. The man brought him to Jesus’s disciples, but they couldn’t help. He said to Jesus, 'I brought him to your disciples, but they couldn’t help me. Why is that?'
All the king’s horses and all the king’s men can’t put your boy back together again. You need the King Himself.
What did Jesus say after the man told Him the disciples couldn’t help? He said, 'Bring him to me.' Folks, that’s what prayer is—bring him to me.

I think of the story of the Prodigal Son. It’s really not about the prodigal son if we study it in context; it’s about the self-righteous older brother. But there’s great hope for parents whose children are out in the world, with the father in the story as a picture of God Himself, showing grace even when the son wastes his inheritance on riotous living.

The father sees him a long way off, and you remember the story, how the father runs to him. The boy starts into his speech he had prepared, gets about half of it out, and the father cuts him off, saying, 'I don’t need to hear your speech, you’re not applying for a job with me, you’re my son. You were dead and you’re alive, you were lost and you’re found, time to party, kill the fatted calf!'
We do know this about Jesus: He came to seek and save that which was lost. He’s the Good Shepherd who will leave the hundred sheep and go find the one who is wandering and bring him home.

My daughter Chrissy backslid, went into the world. My wife became suicidal over it, and though we tried everything, even money, to get her back to the Lord and our family, things just got worse for two and a half years.
At our church, we had a prayer meeting that more people attended than Sunday services. A thousand folks would come out on a Tuesday night to pray for different needs.

During a prayer meeting, someone sent a note up to me on stage saying they felt a burden to pray for my daughter Chrissy right then. I didn’t want to do it, didn’t want the attention on my family, but I felt the Lord say, ‘Do it,’ so I asked the congregation to pray.

I remember coming back some years ago from Lancaster, not too familiar with the area. My mom had moved up there in the final stages of her cancer, and I drove up alone to spend time with her. I had my laptop with some software and a little USB device on the dash acting as my GPS, feeling pretty cool, but it’d just say ‘off route’ if I made a mistake, not telling me where to go, just that I wasn’t in the right place.

I remember putting in the fastest way home on my GPS, thinking, 'Alright, this is why technology pays off, I’m gonna save some time.' But it took me through the Angeles Crest mountains, where I’m sure serial murderers live and die. I almost barfed twice, it took three hours, and I had to keep stopping—it was horrible!

I remember telling some friends the other night with Becky that when we bought my middle son his first two-wheel bicycle, he was so excited. But after falling a few times on the front lawn, he got frustrated, got up off the ground, walked into the house, and said, 'Why did you buy me a bike that always falls down?' It’s gotta be somebody else’s fault.
Mrs. Job, I don’t know what to call her, but she lost her children, I get it. She said to Job, ‘You’re still trusting God after all this? Curse God and die.’

Jesus asked Peter, ‘Who do you say that I am?’ And Simon got it right, man, he nailed it: ‘Thou art the Christ, the Son of the Living God.’ Jesus said, ‘Blessed are you, Simon, son of Jonas, flesh and blood has not revealed this to you, but my Father who is in heaven.’
Do you ever notice God asks questions in the Bible? You go, 'Well, God, I think you kinda know. There's the word of my mouth, you know it already.'
You know what God learns every day? The same thing my son learned every day in sixth grade. I'm asking on the way home, 'What’d you learn?' and he says, 'Nothing. Favorite subject? Lunch and recess.'

Becky and I made some decisions before we got married about never leaving one another in anger. But just two weeks after we got married, I got so mad, I grabbed my keys, said 'I'm out of here,' and got in my car. I didn’t even know where I was going, just that I was showing her who’s boss in this family.

I was 15, working at a gas station, and my mom said, 'You need to take out the trash, clean your room, and then go clean the pool.' I thought, 'Are you kidding me? I'm exhausted, I just got off work, and Lord, they're so unfair!'

When we were kids, we begged neighbors to use their pool 'cause my parents couldn't afford one. Later, when we didn’t care anymore, they built a pool no one used, and guess whose job it was to clean it? Mine, and it was a pain in the neck.
I used to say I got saved because of drugs. I got drugged to church every Sunday, drugged to Sunday school every Sunday. I didn’t have an understanding of who God was or who Jesus was.

I went to a retreat at a church in Virginia. I wasn’t looking for God at all; I just didn’t think you had to find Him—He’s everywhere, right? But He was looking for me, even though I was very rebellious.
Jesus says to Nicodemus, ‘Hey, you have to be born again.’ Nicodemus says, ‘I don’t know what that means. Can I get back inside my mother’s womb?’ It’s like, okay, TMI there, you know.
